Before understanding the true risk of infection and development of effective antiretrovirals, the HIV/AIDS epidemic induced fear and discrimination against groups such as homosexuals, African Americans, and intravenous drug users. Surgeons potentially risked infection when treating patients with HIV/AIDS, as antiretroviral drugs were not available. Both before and after modes of transmission were elucidated, physicians refused to treat patients with HIV/AIDS.
16 One surgeon stated, "I've got to be selfish. It's an incurable disease that's uniformly fatal, and I'm constantly at risk for getting it. I've got to think about myself. I've got to think about my family. That responsibility is greater than to the patient."
